title: check_user_path_2 and _3 are ordered dependent on check_user_path_1
body:
### `brew doctor` output

```shell
Your system is ready to brew.
```

### Verification

- [x] My "`brew doctor` output" above says `Your system is ready to brew.` and am still able to reproduce my issue.
- [x] I ran `brew update` twice and am still able to reproduce my issue.
- [x] This issue's title and/or description do not reference a single formula e.g. `brew install wget`. If they do, open an issue at https://github.com/Homebrew/homebrew-core/issues/new/choose instead.

### `brew config` output

```shell
HOMEBREW_VERSION: 4.4.23
ORIGIN: https://github.com/Homebrew/brew
HEAD: 64efed206deeb9c2304d9e5b5910dcbf0a509c15
Last commit: 7 days ago
Branch: stable
Core tap JSON: 09 Mar 23:50 UTC
Core cask tap JSON: 09 Mar 23:50 UTC
HOMEBREW_PREFIX: /opt/homebrew
HOMEBREW_CASK_OPTS: []
HOMEBREW_EDITOR: vim
HOMEBREW_MAKE_JOBS: 4
Homebrew Ruby: 3.3.7 => /opt/homebrew/Library/Homebrew/vendor/portable-ruby/3.3.7/bin/ruby
CPU: quad-core 64-bit dunno
Clang: 16.0.0 build 1600
Git: 2.39.5 => /Library/Developer/CommandLineTools/usr/bin/git
Curl: 8.7.1 => /usr/bin/curl
macOS: 15.3.1-arm64
CLT: 16.2.0.0.1.1733547573
Xcode: N/A
Rosetta 2: false
```

### What were you trying to do (and why)?

When running the brew doctor checks individually (to determine the name of the check throwing the warning about cirruslabs/cli/tart) I discovered that running `check_user_path_2` and `check_user_path_3` would throw warnings. When those checks are run, but with `check_user_path_1` listed before, they pass. If `check_user_path_2` or `check_user_path_3` occur _before_ `check_user_path_1` then a warning is issued.


### What happened (include all command output)?

```
Please note that these warnings are just used to help the Homebrew maintainers
with debugging if you file an issue. If everything you use Homebrew for is
working fine: please don't worry or file an issue; just ignore this. Thanks!

Warning: Homebrew's "bin" was not found in your PATH.
Consider setting your PATH for example like so:
  echo 'export PATH="/opt/homebrew/bin:$PATH"' >> ~/.zshrc
```


### What did you expect to happen?

```
Your system is ready to brew.
```

### Step-by-step reproduction instructions (by running `brew` commands)

```shell
zsh --norcs -o INTERACTIVE_COMMENTS
brew doctor check_user_path_2 # warning
brew doctor check_user_path_3 # warning, if there is a formula that adds an sbin executable, such as "gnupg" or "unbound"
brew doctor check_user_path_2 check_user_path_1 # warning
brew doctor check_user_path_3 check_user_path_1 # warning, if there is a formula that adds an sbin executable, such as "gnupg" or "unbound"
brew doctor ${(Oa)$(brew doctor --list-checks)} # warning
brew doctor check_user_path_1 check_user_path_2 # PASS
brew doctor check_user_path_1 check_user_path_3 # PASS
brew doctor # PASS
```
